text:
Hello, 
This one is old. It is a known security problem, but disabling it may break
things and make your life much harder (security vs convenience). 
https://cyberplace.social/@GossiTheDog/111499085112278625

(if you do not follow Kevin Beaumont in Mastodon yet and you work in
Patching/ICT Security, you should). 
"I still have an easy way to get SYSTEM on all versions of Windows that is 100%
reliable and has worked for years - there’s a device on Amazon where the driver
installation throws a GUI, which launches a command prompt. 
Deliberately haven’t posted which device to keep the access 
Example and mitigation: 
https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/how-to-block-windows-plug-and-play-auto-installing-insecure-apps/
 
Based on the information I've found, I suspect this: 
It seems that HP has pushed a driver through possibly Windows Update targeting
"Local Printer" instead of their own hardware ID. This partially replaces
existing drivers and, as this driver requires an app (same like nvidia or Intel
control panels), it will download the HP app from the store if the store is
enabled. 
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/printers-showing-as-hp-laserjet-m101-m106/538afaad-fab1-4306-9169-31b790a0e2a7
 
I do not know what triggers or triggered the download of the driver. We haven't
been impacted so far (we have the MS Store and direct access to Windows Update
blocked). I fear this will be a hell to fix for people deploying printer drivers
manually. 
Best regards 
Seve 
Von:  <
%40DBBP189MB1340.EURP189.PROD.OUTLOOK.COM

metadata.email_text_original:
You don't often get email from juan.severino@skan.ch. Learn why this is
important [https://aka.ms/LearnAboutSenderIdentification] 
Hello, 
This one is old. It is a known security problem, but disabling it may break
things and make your life much harder (security vs convenience). 
https://cyberplace.social/@GossiTheDog/111499085112278625
[https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fcyberplace.social%2F%40GossiTheDog%2F111499085112278625&data=05%7C01%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C2275b6aba4504736a56808dbf634c854%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638374478802736929%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=1yb%2FBeIthyJXifUf3WdiSvpfCThHk98k2V%2FETgefPXo%3D&reserved=0]
(if you do not follow Kevin Beaumont in Mastodon yet and you work in
Patching/ICT Security, you should). 
"I still have an easy way to get SYSTEM on all versions of Windows that is 100%
reliable and has worked for years - there’s a device on Amazon where the driver
installation throws a GUI, which launches a command prompt. 
Deliberately haven’t posted which device to keep the access 
Example and mitigation: 
https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/microsoft/how-to-block-windows-plug-and-play-auto-installing-insecure-apps/
[https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.bleepingcomputer.com%2Fnews%2Fmicrosoft%2Fhow-to-block-windows-plug-and-play-auto-installing-insecure-apps%2F&data=05%7C01%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C2275b6aba4504736a56808dbf634c854%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638374478802736929%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=m%2FrAEgZOL7ZNAbphCI2%2FfS3Ik2cd9NmC7qVd00urM4A%3D&reserved=0] 
Based on the information I've found, I suspect this: 
It seems that HP has pushed a driver through possibly Windows Update targeting
"Local Printer" instead of their own hardware ID. This partially replaces
existing drivers and, as this driver requires an app (same like nvidia or Intel
control panels), it will download the HP app  from the store if the store is
enabled. 
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/printers-showing-as-hp-laserjet-m101-m106/538afaad-fab1-4306-9169-31b790a0e2a7
[https://can01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fanswers.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fwindows%2Fforum%2Fall%2Fprinters-showing-as-hp-laserjet-m101-m106%2F538afaad-fab1-4306-9169-31b790a0e2a7&data=05%7C01%7Cemail_ingestion%40bighatgroup.com%7C2275b6aba4504736a56808dbf634c854%7C5a01497e1bcb4711b6e6d24f4ab00393%7C0%7C0%7C638374478802736929%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=b7YzwqoLqfH8fAQcLldc6mcckUJpaUHDALcMcrGj%2BP8%3D&reserved=0] 
I do not know what triggers or triggered the download of the driver. We haven't
been impacted so far (we have the MS Store and direct access to Windows Update
blocked). I fear this will be a hell to fix for people deploying printer drivers
manually. 
Best regards 
Seve 
Von: patchmanagement@googlegroups.com <patchmanagement@googlegroups.com
